journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering

title-group.article-title: Redesign of the vehicle bonnet structure for pedestrian safety

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Mechanical Engineering, Hsiuping University of Science and Technology, Dali, Taichung, Republic of China
2Department of Mechanical Technology, Hung Yen University of Technology and Education, Khoai Chau, Hung Yen, Vietnam

author-notes.corresp: *Department of Mechanical Engineering, Hsiuping University of Science and Technology, 11 Gongye Road, Dali, Taichung 41280, Republic of China. email: tlteng@mail.dyu.edu.tw

abstract.p: Redesign of the structure of the bonnet to improve pedestrian head protection has recently received considerable attention from automobile manufacturers and industry institutes. The fatality of a head injury is based on the head injury criterion (HIC) value. This HIC value is calculated on the basis of the resultant acceleration of the head’s centre of gravity (hereafter called the head centre) during head impacts. This study analyses the constitution of and variation in the resultant acceleration in head-to-bonnet impacts, and how each component of acceleration exactly contributes to the resultant acceleration of the head centre. This study also considers how the structural design parameters affect each component of acceleration. The causes that make the characteristic variation in the resultant acceleration differ from the optimal characteristic pulse will be analysed and discussed in detail. Based on the results of this analysis, the sudden increase in K (the curvature of the head centre’s motion) after several milliseconds of the impact process must be eliminated. The sudden increase in K in this duration does not depend on the mass and stiffness of the bonnet but does depend on the characteristics of the reinforcement structure. Therefore, a new design of the bonnet reinforcement structure has eliminated the sudden increase in K. The bonnet reinforcement structure, as well as the bonnet thickness, have been designed to make the resultant acceleration of the head centre close to the optimal acceleration pulse. The results of this study contribute to efforts to design an improved vehicle bonnet structure and to pave the way for developing pedestrian protection technologies.

kwd-group.kwd: European Enhanced Vehicle-Safety Committee Working Group 17

sec.title: 1 Introduction
sec.p: The World Health Organization has estimated that 1.2 × 106 people are killed worldwide in road traffic crashes and that up to 50 × 106 are injured each year [1]. According to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA), automotive-related accidents in the USA claimed the lives of 4654 pedestrians in 2007 [2], or an average of one fatality every 113 min. Additionally, about 57 per cent of pedestrian fatalities and 75 per cent of pedestrian injuries are attributed to car accidents [3]. The above statistics reflect the urgency within the automotive industry to consider pedestrian safety. Head and face injuries leading to fatality account for 60 per cent of all pedestrian body injuries [4], whereas 17.3 per cent of head injuries were due to the bonnet [5]. The above figures demonstrate the necessity to consider more carefully the bonnet in pedestrian head safety.

The passenger car bonnet consists of two parts, namely the bonnet skin and the bonnet reinforcement, as shown in Fig. 1. Redesign of the structure of the bonnet to improve pedestrian head protection has recently received considerable attention from automobile manufacturers and industry institutes. As is widely recognized, the stiffness of the vehicle surface and the available deformation space are believed to have effects on pedestrian head injury. Therefore, the bonnet design has evolved to reduce the mass and stiffness and to create a more uniform stiffness profile. Figure 2 illustrates a method of protecting pedestrians by creating more holes in the ribs of the reinforcement to reduce the bonnet stiffness [6]. Kalliske and Friesen [5] reduced the bonnet stiffness and mass by reducing the bonnet skin thickness to protect the pedestrian head. Previous research on improving pedestrian safety also increased the number of ribs to create a bonnet surface with a more uniform stiffness. Figure 3 shows the reinforcement structure developed to protect pedestrians in accidents [7]. Currently some automobiles use a multi-cone structure (see Fig. 3) instead of rib structures for bonnet reinforcement. Untaroiu et al. [8] presented the results of hood optimization using simulations of the headform–hood impact test. Carter et al. [9] attempted to demonstrate the feasibility of applying the field of evolutionary computation to the problem of pedestrian safety by using a simple genetic algorithm to optimize the centre-line geometry of a car’s front end for reduction in pedestrian head and thoracic injury.

caption.p: The description of the bonnet structure of passenger car
Pedestrian protection due to a modified original reinforcement structure [6]
Various alternative design solutions for protection of the pedestrian head [7]: (a) traditional design; (b) increased number of ribs; (c) multi-cone design

sec.p: The fatality of a head injury is based on the head injury criterion (HIC) value. The HIC has been devised to predict head injury in the case of an impact with flat objects and considers both main types of brain injury, namely consciousness and linear skull fractures. The HIC value of 1000 is the safety threshold for both adults and children. The severity of head injury increases as the HIC value increases. The European New Car Assessment Program (Euro NCAP) also classified pedestrian protection into five start levels based on the range of HIC values and used a colour coding system to indicate these levels. Table 1 lists the proposed HIC tolerance levels correlated with brain injury and skull fracture [10]. Based on this tolerance, the level of 1800 represents the maximum allowable tolerance of the HIC value, and the level of less than 650 represents the level of no injury.

caption.p: Proposed HIC tolerance levels correlated to brain injury and skull fracture [10]

sec.p: The HIC value is calculated on the basis of the resultant acceleration of the head’s centre of gravity (hereafter referred to as the head centre) during the impact process [11]. The optimal characteristic pulse for resultant acceleration was proposed on the basis of the HIC calculation algorithm, as shown in Fig. 4, with an initially high peak, followed by a lower constant level [12]. This pulse was proposed by Okamoto et al. [13] under the condition that a 2.5 kg headform contacts the bonnet top zones at an impact speed of 40 km/h. The problem is how to design the bonnet to obtain the resultant acceleration of the head centre close to the optimal characteristic pulse. This problem has not been considered until now. The resultant acceleration can be divided into two components with respect to the normal and tangential coordinates, namely the normal and tangential accelerations. The normal acceleration reflects the rate of change in the direction of the head centre’s motion or the rate of change in the direction of the head centre’s velocity vector, while the tangential acceleration reflects the rate of decreasing amplitude of the head centre’s velocity or the loss of the head’s kinetic energy. However, previous studies have disregarded how the normal acceleration at the impact instant affects the HIC value, owing either to the lack of consideration of the change in the direction of the head centre’s motion [7, 14], or the assumption that the head centre’s motion at the impact instant is directed along a straight line [15]. No previous research has assessed how the normal acceleration at the impact instant affects the HIC value. According to the legal stipulation of the European Enhanced Vehicle-safety Committee (EEVC) to evaluate friendliness of the bonnet with the pedestrian head, the impact angle for tests with child and adult headform impactors must be 50° and 65° respectively to the ground reference level [11]. This means that the pedestrian head does not impact the bonnet at a direction normal to the bonnet surface. Restated, the direction of the head centre’s motion may change frequently upon impact or the normal acceleration may significantly contribute to the resultant acceleration of the head centre. Therefore, pedestrian head protection studies should consider how the normal acceleration contributes to the resultant acceleration of the head centre. It is necessary to control the characteristics of the resultant acceleration of the head centre’s approach to the optimal characteristic pulse.

caption.p: Optimal characteristic pulse [12]

sec.p: The problem of how to design the bonnet to obtain a resultant acceleration of the head centre close to the optimal characteristic pulse will be considered in this study. Based on many simulations of the headform-impactor-to-bonnet-top test, this study analyses the constitution of and variation in the resultant acceleration in head-to-bonnet impacts, and how the components of the acceleration (i.e. the normal acceleration and the tangential acceleration) exactly contribute to the resultant acceleration of the head centre. This study also considers how structural design parameters affect each component of the acceleration. The causes that make the characteristic variation in the resultant acceleration differ from the optimal characteristic pulse will be analysed and discussed in detail. On the basis of the results of this analysis, the bonnet reinforcement structure, as well as the bonnet thickness, will be designed to make the resultant acceleration of the head centre close to the optimal acceleration pulse. The results of the study contribute to efforts to design vehicle bonnet structures and to pave the way for developing pedestrian protection technologies.

sec.title: 2.1 Headform-to-bonnet-top test
sec.p: The EEVC has developed test procedures to assess the level of pedestrian protection for vehicle fronts. The EEVC Working Group 17 (WG17) established a series of component tests representing the three most important origins of injury: head, upper leg, and lower leg. The EEVC WG17 developed this method for assessing whether a vehicle is pedestrian friendly. The WG17 tests consist of four models of pedestrian impactors that are typically impacted with four corresponding areas on a vehicle, including child headform, adult headform, upper-legform, and lower-legform impactors. Figure 5 illustrates the pedestrian protection concept proposed by the EEVC WG17 [11]. The European Union has utilized these pedestrian safety regulations for vehicle tests. These EEVC WG17 regulations will be completed and applied to vehicle manufacturing in Europe.

caption.p: Pedestrian protection concept described by the EEVC WG17 [11]

sec.p: Friendliness of the bonnet with the pedestrian head is evaluated using both the EEVC child headform impactor and the EEVC adult headform impactor. The initial impact velocity is 40 km/h (11.11 m/s) for both the child headform impactor and the adult headform impactors. The impact angle for tests with the child headform impactor and adult headform impactor must be 50° and 65° respectively to the ground reference level. The forward section of the bonnet top is tested using the child headform impactor, with the points of the first contact lying between boundaries described by wrap-around distances (WADs) of 1000 mm and 1500 mm or by the rear of the bonnet top, depending on the length of bonnet. The rearward section of the bonnet top is tested using the adult headform impactor, with the points of first contact lying between boundaries described by a WAD of 1500 mm and the rear of the bonnet top or a WAD of 2100 mm for a long bonnet.

sec.title: 2.2 Finite element model and simulation
sec.p: This study analyses the variations in the resultant acceleration of the head centre during the head-to-bonnet-top impact by performing headform impactor tests of the WG17 regulations. Figure 6(b) shows the finite element models of the child and adult headform impactors. The vinyl skin is modelled with viscoelastic material, as well as a steel core with elastic material. All parts of the headform impactors use solid elements. The adult headform impactor model consists of 3713 nodes and 13 783 solid elements. The child headform impactor model consists of 2021 nodes and 7032 solid elements. A previous study by one of the present authors and a co-worker [16] developed and validated these finite element models of headform impactors. Both of the headforms satisfy the EEVC WG17 certification tests, demonstrating the feasibility of their use in simulating headform impactor tests. Both the child headform impactor and the adult headform impactor were used for bonnet top testing.

caption.p: The finite element model using pedestrian-head–bonnet impact simulations: (a) the passenger car model [17]; (b) the headform impactor model [16]

sec.p: Simulations of the headform-impactor-to-bonnet-top test were performed using a Ford Taurus model. The full-vehicle finite element model of a 1992 Ford Taurus is from the National Crash Analysis Center (a Federal Highway Administration (FHWA)–NHTSA–George Washington University collaboration) [17], as shown in Fig. 6(a). Each headform impactor will be used in 36 different positions on the bonnet top, as shown in Fig. 7. Because of symmetrical bonnet reinforcement structures, all impact positions were selected in a half-bonnet surface. The positions impacted by the child headform impactor are located between a WAD of 1000 mm and a WAD of 1500 mm. The positions impacted by the adult headform impactor are located between a WAD of 1500 mm and the rear reference line.

caption.p: The positions that were selected for impact by the child and the adult headform impactors

sec.p: The conditions of simulation were set on the basis of the EEVC WG17 regulations. The impact angles selected for the child headform impactor tests and adult headform impactor tests are 50° and 65° respectively to the ground reference level. The impact velocity for both the child headform impactor and the adult headform impactor is 40 km/h.

sec.title: 2.3 Processing of output data
sec.p: The fatality criterion for head injury is based on the HIC value. The HIC value is calculated on the basis of the resultant acceleration of the head centre during impact from instant T1 to instant T2. Given that T1 is less than T2, the HIC value is defined as
with the condition

where A denotes the resultant acceleration of the head centre (in units of g), and T1 and T2 are the two time instants (in seconds). Notably, A can be expressed with respect to the coordinates according to
with

where An and At denote the normal acceleration and the tangential acceleration, respectively, K denotes the curvature of the head centre’s motion, and V denotes the resultant velocity of the head centre.

The rules for the variation in A as well as the variations in other parameters such as An and At can be determined from the outputs of the simulations. The HIC value and duration (T1, T2) for HIC calculation are also determined. When the above data are determined, the average values of A, An, and At in the duration (T1, T2) are determined as
Next, An and At in the duration (T1, T2) are compared by using the ratio R of the average value of An to the average value of At in this duration. It is determined as

If the headform impactor’s centre moves in a straight line during the impact process, then An equals zero for all the range; hence, the value of R also equals zero. The values of R will be used to estimate the contribution of An to the HIC and the characteristics of the variation in A.

sec.title: 3 Analysis of the Design of the Pedestrian-Friendly Bonnet
3.1 Effect of the normal acceleration on the HIC value and the characteristics of the resultant acceleration
sec.p: Table 2 lists the values of R and HIC obtained from simulations of the impacts of headforms onto 72 positions on the original bonnet top (Fig. 7). There are only six of the 72 positions at which the R values are less than one, and the HIC values corresponding to these positions are not very high. At the remaining positions, the R values are greater than one. At some positions the value of R is even greater than two, with extremely high corresponding HIC values. This finding suggests that An contributes significantly to the HIC values.

caption.p: Results of simulation of the impacts of headforms on the original bonnet top

sec.p: Figure 8 presents the variation bounds of At, An, and A from the 72 simulations in comparison with the optimal characteristic pulse. According to this figure, the value of At is only high in the first 5 ms; thereafter, At becomes rather small and A is almost decided by An. Thus, the variation in An after 5 ms will decide the characteristics of A close to the optimal characteristic pulse or not. The normal acceleration An is defined using K and V2 as shown in equation (4). Figure 9 shows the variation bounds of An, K, and V2 from the 72 simulations. This figure shows that the variation corridor of V2 is quite narrow, implying that the values of V in different positions during simulation are close to each other. The bounding corridor of K is also extremely narrow in the first few milliseconds; thereafter, the bounding corridor of K becomes extremely wide, implying that the K value significantly varies at different impact positions. Figure 10 compares the values of K at six positions of R values, with R less than one, as well as at six other positions with increasing values of R selected. After several milliseconds, K stabilizes for all positions with R values less than one, whereas K significantly increases at positions at which R is greater than one.

caption.p: The variation bounds of At, An, and A from simulations that were carried out
The variation bounds of K, V2, and An from simulations that were carried out
A comparison of the variations in K for various positions with different R values

sec.p: Closely examining the changes in V2, K, and An during the impact process reveals that An has only one low and narrow peak if the K value of the impact process does not significantly increase, as shown in Fig. 11, whereas, if there is any instant at which K dramatically increases, An also has similar trends owing to a steady decrease in V2, as shown in Fig. 12. Therefore, dramatically increasing K significantly affects the characteristics of the variation in A. If K does not significantly increase during the impact process, A has only one peak that is very close to the optimal characteristic pulse, as shown in Fig. 13, whereas, if An has more than one peak because of the significant increase in K, the trend of A variation resembles that of An. Therefore, the characteristics of the A curve differ extremely from the optimal characteristic pulse, as shown in Fig. 14. If A has more than one peak because of a sudden increase in K, the duration for HIC calculation is longer. Figure 8 also shows that upper bound of An is not very high in the first few milliseconds. When the duration for HIC calculation is increasing, the average value At in this duration will decrease significantly, and even the average value An in this duration increases because of the following peak of An. Therefore, the significant increase in K also causes the value of R to be significantly higher than one.

caption.p: The characteristics of An variation in the case when K does not increase suddenly again
The characteristics of An variation in the case when K increases suddenly again
The characteristics of A variation in the case when K does not increase suddenly again
The characteristics of A variation in the case when K increases suddenly again

sec.p: The above discussion suggests that designing bonnets with respect to pedestrian protection largely depends on how to control the variation in K. Reducing the HIC value requires controlling the value of K during the first 5 ms to be as low as possible; thereafter, K does not significantly increase again. Simulation results indicate that there are some positions at which K does not increase after the first few milliseconds. This implies that K can be totally controlled by altering the mechanical properties of the impact position. The next section analyses how the variation in K and the properties of the impact position are related to the origin of the K variation.

sec.title: 3.2 Analysis of the cause of the variation in the curvature of the motion
sec.p: Notably, K is the directional change in the rate of the head centre’s motion, or the rate of the change in the direction of the head centre’s velocity vector. During the impact process, the head centre simultaneously moves in two directions, tangentially and normally. They are tangential and normal to the bonnet surface in the initial state (i.e. the state when the bonnet has not been deformed because of a collision), as shown in Fig. 15. When the headform impactor begins to make contact with bonnet top, Vn significantly decreases because it is impeded by the bonnet surface, whereas Vt decreases slightly because the surface of the bonnet top is rather smooth at this moment. Therefore, the rate K of the change in the direction of the velocity vector depends on the decreasing rate of Vn. However, the decreasing rate of Vn depends on the stiffness and the mass of the bonnet because the energy due to the decrease in Vn is transferred to the deflection of the bonnet surface. Thus, the variation in K in the first few milliseconds is decided by the stiffness and the mass of the bonnet. This finding explains the reason why the bound of K is narrow for the first few milliseconds and a similar variation rule at different impact positions. Thus, the main peak of A during the first 5 ms is decided by the mass and the stiffness of the bonnet.

caption.p: Description of the kinetics of the headform impactor during impact

sec.p: Because of the deflection, the bonnet surface is inclined at an angle φ(t) compared with the bonnet surface in the initial state, as shown in Fig. 15. If there is any instant at which φ(t) is extremely high, then both movements of the head centre are impeded strongly at that time. Therefore, the moving direction of the head centre suddenly changes; otherwise, the value of K significantly increases. The variations in K obtained from simulation at positions C25 and C32 significantly differ from each other, as shown in Fig. 16. This figure also compares the corresponding Vn and Vt. Although the variations in Vn closely resemble each other, the two variations in Vt differ somewhat. At position C32, K does not increase further after several milliseconds, and Vt gradually decreases in the whole time range, whereas, at position C25, there is an instant at which K suddenly increases, and Vt decreases more rapidly than it does at position C32. At the instant when K increases suddenly, the decreasing rate of Vt and Vn are approximately equal to each other. Thus, any impediment that causes Vt to decrease at a high rate causes K to increase suddenly. Restated, the large angle of φ(t) explains the sudden diversion of the head centre’s direction of motion during impact.

caption.p: The effects of the variation in the velocity components on the K variation

sec.p: The bonnet surface has a sheet structure with its own low stiffness. The stiffness of the whole bonnet is raised owing to the support of the reinforcement, which is a deep-drawn sheet metal structure. If impact positions are located on the hole of a reinforcement structure, the bonnet skin is easily deformed and deflected whereas, owing to the inertia, the stiffness of the reinforcement, and the indirect influence of the impact force on the reinforcement ribs, reinforcement is not deflected immediately, but a short time afterwards. This feature means that the bonnet surface does not deflect smoothly on the whole but becomes more deflective at the impact positions. Therefore, a deep valley is created at the impact position at the beginning of the impact process and the angle φ(t) becomes extremely large.

Simulation results indicate that all positions with the value of R smaller than one are located on the ribs of the reinforcement. Those positions have a higher stiffness than positions located on the holes of the reinforcement structure. However, during impact at the positions located on the ribs of the reinforcement, both the bonnet skin and the reinforcement are directly affected by the impact force. Therefore, both the bonnet skin and the bonnet reinforcement are deflected simultaneously. In this case the bonnet surface is deflected smoothly on the whole surface and both the angle φ(t) and the impediment of Vt are small.

Although position C33 is located on the reinforcement rib, simulation results shows that the HIC values, as well as the R value in this position, are extremely high (Table 2). Simulation results indicate that a strong fluctuation occurs when the child headform impacts at position C33. Figure 17 shows the variations in the impact force and K when impacting at position C33. The impact force significantly decreases and then increases sharply. Simultaneously, K suddenly increases at an extremely high rate. The sudden increase in the impact force is the result of bonnet fluctuation. If the reinforcement structure fluctuates, there is an instant when the impact position is moving down while the surrounding area moves upwards and the angle φ(t) increases. The fluctuation in the reinforcement increases not only the impediment to movement in the direction of Vt but also the impediment to movement in the direction of Vn. Movements in both the Vn direction and the Vt direction are impeded suddenly, causing the moving direction to be diverted or K to increase suddenly.

caption.p: The effect of the reinforcement structure fluctuation on the K variation

sec.title: 4.1 Design of the bonnet reinforcement structure
sec.p: The structures of bonnet reinforcement were redesigned to eliminate the sudden increase in K during impact. In the new reinforcement structures, many short ribs which are arranged in different directions are used instead of long ribs which stretch across the bonnet. The reinforcement ribs are arranged to attain uniform mass and stiffness, as shown in Fig. 18. With this arrangement of reinforcement ribs, the impact energy is transferred evenly along the ribs in different directions about the impact positions, and so the large area surrounding the impact positions will sag downwards during the impact process. Moreover, the area of the reinforcement hole is reduced to avoid the creation of a deep valley at impact positions when the head impacts the reinforcement holes. Therefore, the pedestrian head can slip smoothly on the bonnet surface during impact. Because the reinforcement ribs are arranged like this, it will also reduce the reactive energy at the impact position because the reactive energy will be transferred from the support system to the whole bonnet surface along the reinforcement ribs. The uniform mass and stiffness, as well as the decrease in the reactive energy at the impact position, make the bonnet fluctuate less and, therefore, reduce the reaction of the bonnet when applied to the pedestrian head.

caption.p: New design of the bonnet reinforcement structure (the dimensions are given in millimetres)

sec.p: In the preliminary design, the diameter of the inscribed circle of reinforcement holes was chosen as 130 mm (equal to the diameter of the child headform impactor). The width of the reinforcement ribs was reduced from 165 mm to 130 mm, and the other dimensions in the right cross-section of the reinforcement ribs were retained at their original values. Table 3 lists the values of R and HIC obtained from simulations of the headform impact at the 72 positions shown in Fig. 7, but the reinforcement was replaced by the new structure shown in Fig. 18. At only seven of the 72 positions are the R values slightly greater than one and, at the remaining positions, the R values are less than one. Figure 19 shows the variation bounds of K obtained from the simulations with the new design of the reinforcement structure. In a comparison of the variation bounds of K obtained from the new design with those from the original bonnet, it was found that the upper bound of K in the new structure is much lower than that of the original. The bounding corridor of K from the new design is extremely narrow and low in the first 10 ms. The bounding corridor of K becomes quite wide after about 15 ms, implying that the K value increases significantly at some positions. After about 15 ms, the bonnet deflection reaches the maximal value and then the headform impactors change direction upwards; therefore, the K value will increase significantly. However, the increase in K at this time insignificantly affects An as well as A because the value of V is quite small. This feature makes the bounding corridor of A close to the optimal characteristic pulse, as shown in Fig. 20. Thus, this controlled characteristic of the variation in A is similar to the optimal characteristic pulse. However, the upper bound of A is higher than the optimal characteristic pulse, demonstrating that the main peak of A is still high at some positions. This feature explains why the HIC value at many positions is greater than the safety threshold, as shown in Table 3. As mentioned above, the main peak of A in the first few milliseconds is decided by the mass and the stiffness of the bonnet. Thus, the dimensions which were chosen for the reinforcement structure can be accepted, but the thicknesses of the bonnet have to be adjusted to obtain a suitable bonnet stiffness. The following sections will present a method to choose the most effective thicknesses for the new bonnet structure to protect pedestrians and to make the bonnet as stiff as possible.

caption.p: Results of simulation of the impacts of headforms on the bonnet with the new reinforcement
A comparison of the bounds of K for the original and the new designs of reinforcement
A comparison of the bounds of A for the original and the new designs of reinforcement

sec.title: 4.2 Design of the bonnet thicknesses
sec.p: The combined LS-DYNA and LS-OPT were used to determine the most effective values for new design of bonnet reinforcement and bonnet skin. The algorithm of response surface methodology is supported in LS-OPT to optimize the design variables based on the theory of experimental analysis [18]. This approach was also used to increase the number of positions on the bonnet which are considered to be pedestrian friendly.

sec.title: 4.2.1 Optimal design function
sec.p: The requirement for a pedestrian-friendly bonnet means that it should be not only safer for pedestrians but should also be as stiff as possible. Thus, the optimal function to design the bonnet thickness can be described as

where X is a design variable and is equal to [X1, X2] with X1 and X2 the reinforcement and bonnet skin thicknesses, respectively. D(X) is an objective function which is the deflection of the bonnet at the considered position during the impact process. The components in the engine room that are most vulnerable to impact are on the top of the engine, and thus the positions on the bonnet surface above the top of the engine is selected to consider bonnet deflection. HICi(X) is a constraint function expressing the dependence of the HIC value on the bonnet reinforcement thickness X1 and the bonnet skin thickness X2. The function HICi(X) is designed using regression analysis.

sec.title: 4.2.2 Design constraints
sec.p: The new design of the bonnet reinforcement structure has eliminated the sudden increase in K, and now only the mass and the stiffness of the bonnet have effects on the HIC value. Therefore, if the bonnet thicknesses are adjusted to reduce the highest HIC value to be lower than the safety threshold, the HIC value at the other positions will also be lower than the safety threshold. Thus, the position with the greatest HIC value in each area which is likely to cause injury to the pedestrian head will be chosen to design constraints for the optimal function. According to the results given in Table 3, the positions A25, A64, A66, C12, C24, and C56 will be chosen to design the constraints. A regression analysis is used to design the constraints which are functions giving the relationship between the HIC value and the design variable at these positions. The accuracy of the polynomial approximation increases with increasing order of the regression function. However, the required number of sampling times increases with increasing order of the regression function, thus increasing the time required for sampling. In this research, the order of the regression function HICi(X) is chosen as the first order. Therefore, it is necessary to carry out sampling at least five times with different values of two variables [18]. Table 4 lists the thicknesses used in the sampling process and the corresponding HIC values obtained from simulating the impact at the selected positions. These data will be used to design the constraint for the optimal function by the regression technique. Table 5 presents the regression functions that give the relationship between the HIC value and the thicknesses of the reinforcement and the bonnet skin. Although the accuracy of polynomial approximation is quite high, this result is acceptable in comparison with the tolerance of the HIC value (see Table 1). Therefore, these functions will be used as constraints for the above optimal function to determine the most effective values for the thicknesses of the new bonnet reinforcement structure and the bonnet skin.

caption.p: Sampling results for the design constraints obtained by the regression technique

tr.th: HIC value for the following positions

caption.p: Results of the design constraint functions obtained by the regression technique

sec.title: 4.3 Results and discussion
sec.p: The above optimal function and constraints are used to determine the most effective values for the thicknesses of the bonnet reinforcement and the bonnet skin. Figure 21 shows the optimization histories of X1 (the thickness of the reinforcement) and X2 (the thickness of the bonnet skin). The optimal thicknesses of the bonnet reinforcement and the bonnet skin are 0.8352 mm and 0.8016 mm, respectively. Both the reinforcement thickness and the bonnet skin thickness decrease in comparison with the original values. Thus, for the new design of the bonnet, the thickness values of the bonnet reinforcement and the bonnet skin can be chosen to be 0.84 mm and 0.80 mm, respectively. Table 6 shows the HIC values as well as the R values obtained from repeated simulations of the headform impact at 72 selected positions, as shown in Fig. 7, where the bonnet is replaced by the new design bonnet (i.e. the new design for the bonnet reinforcement structure and the new values of the thicknesses). These results show that the HIC values are slightly greater than the safety threshold at ten of the 72 positions, while the HIC values are below the safety threshold at the remaining positions. All positions with a high HIC value are located in the rearward or forward area of bonnet surface where the support system is located. There is no position with an HIC value at the level of fatality, while at six of the 72 positions the HIC values are below 650, the level of no injury. The new design of the bonnet identified in this study is thus more friendly to a pedestrian head than is the original design. According to the results in Table 6, the values of R in five of the 72 positions are insignificantly greater than one, while the R values are lower than one at the remaining positions. These results demonstrated that the sudden increase in K is eliminated in the new design bonnet.

caption.p: Optimal history of the design variables
Results of simulation of the impacts of headforms on the new bonnet design

sec.p: Figure 22 shows a comparison between the deflections of the bonnet surface at the impact positions of the original and the new bonnet designs. At some positions the deflection of the new bonnet is greater than that of the original bonnet, but at other positions the deflection of the new bonnet design is less than that of the original bonnet. Although there are differences between the bonnet deflections of the original bonnet and the new bonnet design, the ranges of deflection values are almost similar for the original and the new bonnets.

caption.p: A comparison of the deflections of the bonnet surface at the different impact positions

sec.p: The torsional stiffness of the bonnet was defined as the ratio of the vertical force to the bonnet corner vertical displacement, and the requirement is not lower than 20 N/mm [19]. Simulations of the torsional stiffness of bonnet testing are performed for both the original bonnet and the new bonnet design. Only the bonnet skin and the bonnet reinforcement are retained for this simulation. The testing conditions are set as shown in Fig. 23, and the load of 100 N applied to position D in the vertical direction. In the case of a downward load, the measured torsional stiffnesses of the bonnets are 37.96 N/mm and 36.74 N/mm for the original bonnet and the new bonnet, respectively. In the case of an upward load, the torsional stiffness of the new design bonnet is 38.91 N/mm, in comparison with 38.89 N/mm for the original bonnet. In comparison with the original bonnet, the new design is more pedestrian friendly, but the stiffness almost does not change.

caption.p: Constraints for the torsional stiffness of the bonnet tests

sec.title: 5 Conclusions
sec.p: By splitting all parameters constituting A, analysing their variations, and evaluating how each parameter affects the characteristics of A and the HIC value, this study demonstrates how each parameter affects the characteristics of the variation in A and the HIC value. The characteristics of the variation in A, in the first few milliseconds after the headform impactor comes into contact with the bonnet surface, are decided by the stiffness and the inertia of the bonnet. Thus, reducing A in this duration requires reducing the stiffness and the inertia of the bonnet. During the next period, the characteristics of A are decided by the variation in K. If K does not increase during this period, A is extremely low and the whole curve of A includes only one low and narrow peak. The curve of A in this case is extremely close to the optimal characteristics pulse. In contrast, if K significantly increases during this period, A is extremely high and the curve of A includes some high peaks adjoining each other. Additionally, the characteristics of A differ from the optimal characteristics pulse, and the duration for HIC calculation is extremely long. In this case, the HIC value is significantly higher than the case in which the curve of A has only one peak with the approximate maximum values of A.

To ensure that the curve of A meets the optimal acceleration pulse, the sudden increase in K after several milliseconds of the impact process must be eliminated. The sudden increase in K in this duration does not depend on the mass and the stiffness of the bonnet but depends on the characteristics of the reinforcement structure. In this study, a new design of the bonnet reinforcement structure which can eliminate the sudden increase in K has been proposed. The new design of the bonnet reinforcement structure has eliminated the sudden increase in K. However, the HIC value is still greater than the safety threshold at many positions. Thus, the stiffness of the bonnet is adjusted for pedestrian friendliness by selecting the most effective values for the bonnet skin and the reinforcement thicknesses. The new bonnet design is more pedestrian friendly, but the stiffness almost does not change in comparison with that of the original bonnet. Therefore, the new bonnet design can be used instead of the original bonnet for pedestrian protection.

fn.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
